intro: Cirsium subcoriaceum, commonly known as the rough thistle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its spiny, lobed leaves that are covered in a rough, hairy texture. The plant produces purple to pinkish flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in meadows, wastelands, and along roadsides. Cirsium subcoriaceum is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers.
